Lignin-derived products possess high carbon content and offer significant potential to be used as liquid fuels. However, they also contain high oxygen element and unstable functional groups. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is an effective method for upgrading lignin-derived phenolic compounds to produce high-quality liquid biofuels. In this study, a series of Ni-based phosphate catalysts incorporating various metals (Al, Ce, La) were prepared and employed for the HDO of lignin-derived phenolic compounds. The results showed that Ni/AlPO4 had the most efficient HDO performance, with guaiacol conversion of 99.9 % and cyclohexane selectivity of 91.1 % at the reaction temperature of 250 °C. Various catalyst characterization measurements were conducted to assess the impact of metal phosphate species on the crystallography, morphology, physicochemical characteristics and surface properties. Results indicated that Ni/AlPO4 catalyst exhibited stronger acidity, smaller Ni particle sizes and larger specific surface area than other Ni-based phosphate catalysts. Based on the characterization results and experimental data, the corresponding HDO reaction pathways and mechanisms were also proposed. Ni/AlPO4 catalyst was also applied to the HDO of various lignin-derived phenol compounds and achieved a good HDO effect. Moreover, the catalytic upgrading of lignin-oil was also carried out, and a high proportion of hydrocarbon products that increased from 16.0 % to 88.6 % was obtained. This Ni/AlPO4 catalyst provides potential reference for the HDO application of lignin-derived phenolic compounds for the production of hydrocarbon liquid fuels. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lignin Hydrodeoxygenation Phenolic compounds Cyclohexane Ni-based phosphate catalyst Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction With the exhaustion of fossil fuels and the pollution problem of fossil fuels combustion, the development of green and renewable energy sources is urgent to solve the energy problem [1]. The production of liquid fuels from biomass is a renewable and clean way to replace the fossil fuels. Lignin, one of the three main components of biomass, has high carbon content and high energy density, which can be used as high-quality fuel or fuel additive [2]. Lignin has a complex three-dimensional structure and can be efficiently converted into energy-rich biofuels through fast pyrolysis [3,4]. The addition of catalyst enables to promote the reaction efficiency significantly. However, lignin-oil produced by catalytic fast pyrolysis usually has disadvantages such as high oxygen content and unstable functional groups, which limits their usage and storage. Therefore, improving the quality of pyrolysis lignin-oil to widen their utilization is necessary. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) as an effective method for refining lignin-oil is considered as one of the most promising strategies, because it can be carried out under mild conditions and offers the advantages of deoxygenation to increase the calorific value [5]. Catalyst plays a key role to promote the HDO efficiency [6], and the HDO catalysts typically possess the metal center for catalytic hydrogenation procedure and the acid support for catalytic deoxygenation procedure. The upgrading of lignin-derived guaiacol to hydrocarbons is a multi-process step involving the breaking of chemical bonds such as CO, CH bonds, etc. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is a common approach, which mainly includes hydrogenation and deoxygenation steps. The metal sites with empty D orbitals can easily adsorb hydrogen, and at the same time convert hydrogen into active hydrogen to complete the hydrogenation process on the benzene ring with active hydrogen. In the deoxygenation process, the acid sites have unique deoxygenation activity through dehydration [7,8]. Therefore, the synergistic effect of metal site and acid site is crucial for improving the activity and selectivity of HDO catalysts. The difference of acid and metal center property leads to different reaction products. Metal center usually includes metal sulfide, noble metal and transition metal. Different active metal phases have different effect on the conversion of phenolic compounds. Kim et al. [9] elucidated the effect of S element doping on the low temperature guaiacol HDO reactivity carried out by Ru/TiO2, and they found that the low temperature activity of the catalysts with deoxygenation was enhanced with the increase of S loading. However, metal sulfides require a constant source of sulfur to be replenished during usage, and sulfides are susceptible to deactivation with oxygen [10]. Noble metals are commonly utilized in hydrogenation and dehydrogenation reactions due to their ability to uptake hydrogen and dissociate hydrogen molecules, but the high economic cost limits their application. Transition metals are commonly employed as substitutes for noble metals. Recent studies have shown that Ni [11–13], Co [14,15], and Mo [16,17] also exhibit effective catalytic hydrogenation properties. Ni-based metals are widely used in catalytic HDO reaction due to their low cost and non-pollution, as well as high catalytic activity at low temperatures [11]. Zhang et al. [18] achieved a conversion of guaiacol of more than 95 % in dodecane solvent at 300 °C using Ni/SiO2-ZrO2 composite supports catalysts with a hydrocarbon yield of 62.81 % after upgrading of lignin-oil. The study also found that the HDO activity of Ni-based catalysts was largely dependent on the characteristics of the support. Acid sites are prominently employed in the catalytic deoxygenation reactions [19–21]. These acid sites expedite the deoxygenation process, including dehydration and hydrogenation steps those are extensively involved in HDO process [22]. Song et al. [23] reported a one-pot method for the conversion of decane from δ-furylidene acetylpropionic acid over phosphotungstic acid-conjugated Pd/C catalysts in a decane yield of 89.53 % and attributed this high yield to the synergistic effect of the metal site and the strong Brønsted acid site. Patrick et al. [24] found that phosphorus-modified platinum-based catalysts promoted the coexistence of oxygen vacancies and strong Brønsted acids. This resulted in a selectivity of over 67 % for toluene. An excessive increase in acid strength can also lead to the cracking of product. Zuo et al. [25] found that the conversion of methyl palmitate over the less acidic Ni/SAPO-11 was higher than that of the more acidic Ni/ZSM-5 in the production of chain alkane compounds, and the difference was attributed to the fact that more acidic Ni/ZSM-5 promoted cracking side-reaction during the conversion process. Peng et al. [26] conducted the quantitative conversion of microalgae oil to diesel range alkanes using Ni/H-beta catalysts. Ni/HZSM-5 was the most acidic when the Si/Al ratio was 45, but the proportion of cracking products produced by side reactions reached 42.7 %. In contrast Ni/HZSM-5 with a decreasing acid density at an Si/Al of 200 also shows a decrease in the proportion of cracking products from side reactions to 7.2 %. Guan et al. [27] constructed a Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst using the synergistic effect of metal/acid and achieved 96.4 % selectivity of cyclohexane as the product in the HDO reaction of diphenyl ether to cyclohexane at 200 °C and 3.0 MPa. Similarly, Kim et al. [28] investigated the complete HDO of vanillin to produce cycloalkanes by constructing a bifunctional catalyst Ru/HZSM-5 which showed a 40-fold increase in the efficiency as compared to a single metal site catalyst, which was attributed to the synergistic effect of the metal site and the acid site. This demonstrates that the synergistic interaction between metal and acid sites is beneficial for HDO reactions, although the exact mechanisms of this synergy remain to be elucidated. In this study, we explored the HDO process of lignin-derived phenols by synthesizing various metal phosphates (Ce, Al, La) as carriers for loading transition metal Ni. The choice of metal species significantly influenced the catalyst properties. Notably, Ni/AlPO4 exhibited superior activity in the conversion of guaiacol. We further investigated various catalytic conditions of Ni/AlPO4 to identify key factors impacting the HDO process. Based on the analysis of the structural features and the corresponding catalytic properties, a mechanism for the selective conversion of lignin-derived phenols to cycloalkanes has been proposed. This work presents an eco-friendly and practical method for preparing stable bis-acidic solid acid catalysts, enhancing biomass utilization efficiency. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Phosphoric acid 85 % (H3PO4, ≥99.8 %), aluminum isopropoxide (Al(O-i-Pr)3, ≥98 %), triethylamine (Et3N, ≥99 %), Cerium(III) nitrate (99 %), lanthanum nitrate (99 %), Octane (96 %), Diphenyl ether (98 %), 4-Propylguaiacol (98 %), Anisole (99 %), p-Cresol (98 %), Guaiacol (99 %), Phenol (AR) were purchased from Macklin Reagan. All reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Lignin-oil, derived from Zhu's Group at the University of Science and Technology of China, was produced following reported procedures for pyrolysis of cotton straw [29]. 2.2 Catalyst preparation AlPO4 catalysts were prepared as described in previous studies [30] using a gel composition of (molar ratios) 1∼1.5Al2O3:1P2O5:1Et3N:45H2O. Al(O-i-Pr)3(14.30 g∼21.45 g, 0.07 mol∼0.105 mol) was added to 23 mL distilled water and the mixture vigorously stirred for 0.5 h. Then a solution of 85 % H3PO4 (8.07 g, 0.07 mmol) in 5 mL distilled water was added dropwise and the resulting solution stirred for 2 h. Subsequently, Et3N (4.9 mL) was added slowly followed by stirring for another 1 h where the solution was transferred to an autoclave, which was tightly closed and kept at 180 °C under autogenous pressure for 48 h. After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature and the obtained product washed with distilled water and ethanol several times, oven dried at 100 °C for 12 h and finally calcined at 550 °C for 7 h. Similarly, CePO4 and LaPO4 were prepared, except that the precursor solutions were replaced with the corresponding nitrate solutions. The other phosphates were synthesized in a molar ratio of 1∼1.5 Ce/La:1P2O5:1Et3N:45 H2O. The next procedure involves mixing a specific amount of support with either Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O solution. After impregnating for 3 h under stirring condition, the solution was heated to 80 °C slowly to evaporate the water and dried at 100 °C overnight. To achieve the metal oxide reduction, the sample was calcined in a slow stream of H2 flow (5 vol% H2/Ar) at 550 °C for 4 h. Theoretically, the catalysts prepared were loaded with 20 wt.% of Ni metal, based on the support's weight. 2.3 Catalyst characterization N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were collected on the Micromeritics ASAP 2460 micropore size analyzer at 77 K. The crystalline structures of the catalysts were characterized by XRD (X-ray diffraction) using a MiniFlex 600 instrument with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54059 Å). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on a ThermoFisher Nexsa. Samples were degassed at 150 °C for 12 h under vacuum prior to measurement. Sample acidity was studied with temperature programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer coupled with a thermal conductivity detector. H2-TPD (H2-programmed temperature desorption) was carried out on a chemisorption instrument equipped TCD detector (BELCAT-A). The thermogravimetric analysis measurements were performed on a HITACHI STA200 simultaneous thermal analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min from room temperature to 800 °C. 2.4 HDO of lignin-derived phenolic compounds and raw lignin-oil In a typical HDO reaction, 0.05 g catalyst, 0.1 g phenolic compounds and 20 mL octane solvent were charged into a 50 mL 316 L stainless steel autoclave (MSG50-P5-T3-SS1-SV-R, Anhui Kemi Machinery Technology Co., Ltd). After purging with H2 to 1 MPa at atmospheric temperature (displacing air for three times at first), the reactor was heated to a certain temperature (6 °C/min rate) under the stirring rate of 500 r/min. After a certain reaction time, the mixture was cooled down to room temperature. Then, the catalyst was removed from the reaction mixture, and the remained solvent was analyzed by gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GC–MS). The test column used for GC-MS was TG-WAXMS (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) and the carrier gas was 99 % high-purity He. The heating procedure of the column was as follows: the initial temperature of 35 °C was held for 5 min, then the temperature was increased to 80 °C at 3 °C /min rate, and then to 240 °C at 15 °C /min and held for 5 min. Product analysis substrate conversion was calculated by Eq. (1) and product selectivity was calculated by Eq. (2) (1) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = 100 × m o l e s o f i n i t i a l G U A − m o l e s o f r e m a i n i n g G U A m o l e s o f i n i t i a l G U A (2) S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = 100 × m o l e s o f p r o d u c t i ∑ m o l e s o f p r o d u c t The HDO reaction of lignin-oil was conducted following the method mentioned earlier. In the reactor, 0.05 g of catalyst and 20 mL of octane were added along with phenolic components extracted from 3 g of crude lignin-oil. The content of the final product was determined based on the ratio of peak areas. Catalysts were subjected to recycle experiments by centrifuging and vacuum drying after the first reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The catalytic activity is greatly affected by the surface structure of the catalyst, and the BET properties of the different catalysts are summarized in Table 1 , with the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms shown in Fig. S1. Ni/CePO4 and Ni/LaPO4 showed type I adsorption curves with mesoporous structure, while Ni/AlPO4 showed type IV isotherms with mesoporous structure and H3 hysteresis curves at P/P0 = 0.8-1.0. The specific surface area of Ni/AlPO4 (116.48 m2 g−1) is the largest among the three catalysts. Generally, large specific surface area and suitable pore volume can enhance the adsorption rate of substrate and chemical mass transfer [31]. The pore sizes of the three catalysts present little difference, but the pore volume of Ni/AlPO4 is much larger than that of the other two catalysts. This is related to the formation of molecular sieve-like ordered structure of aluminium phosphate during calcination process [32]. XRD was used to study the crystal facets of the Ni-based catalysts, and the characteristics are shown in Fig. 1 . As for Ni/CePO4 and Ni/LaPO4 catalysts, the broad diffraction peaks at 5-20° and 50-80° indicate the amorphous structure. The Ni diffraction peaks can be observed in all the samples, demonstrating that all the phosphate supports are successfully loaded with Ni metal phase. In addition to the corresponding specific crystal structure (PDF#41-0044) in Ni/AlPO4 catalyst, the Ni crystal diffraction peaks (PDF#04-0850) are observed at 44.5 ° for Ni (111) and 51.84 ° for Ni (200) facets, respectively. Only one specific crystal type corresponding to the metal phosphate is observed in each of the different catalysts, which indicates the stability of the phosphate structure. The surface composition and electronic state of the Ni-based catalyst were analyzed using XPS measurement, as patterns shown in Fig. 2 . The Ni2p spectrum of the Ni-based phosphate catalyst mainly includes the peaks of metallic Ni (Ni0) at 852.5 eV and 869.8 eV, Ni2+ peaks at 856.0 eV and 874.0 eV, and a shake-up satellite peak at 861.7 eV. As for the P2p spectrum, the peak at 133.9 eV is attributed to the P5+ species. The results clearly indicate that the binding energy of metallic Ni0 in Ni/AlPO4 catalyst is higher (852.68 eV) compared to the other catalysts, suggesting that the presence of Al has reduced the electron cloud density of Ni metal atoms. Concurrently, there is a positive shift in the binding energy of Ni2+, associated with a decrease of the relative standard binding energy of Al species (75.6 eV) (Fig. S2) and a change in the binding energy of P element. This phenomenon indicates that the electron flow of Ni species in Ni/AlPO4 is directed towards the Al species. The charge transfer confirms the strong interaction between Ni and AlPO4. By comparing the Ni0/Ni2+ ratios of the three different catalysts (Table S1), the Ni/AlPO4 ratio is within the appropriate range (1.28), and it proves that the metallicity of Ni0 is more stable on AlPO4. To further observe the microstructure and distribution characteristics of the catalysts, TEM measurements are also conducted. As shown in Fig. 3 , the TEM images reveal a uniform distribution of Ni nanoparticles within the phosphate matrix. Fig. 3a displays the spherical appearance of AlPO4 in Ni/AlPO4 sample, which is benefited from the hydrothermal synthesis process [33]. In contrast, Ni/CePO4 and Ni/LaPO4 exhibit a more rod-like morphology, and this dense morphology probably contributes to their small specific surface area (Fig. 3b and c). Statistical analysis of the particles presents the particle size distribution of Ni metal. The Ni particle size of Ni/AlPO4 (mean size = 13.15 nm) is the smallest among the three different catalysts. High-resolution TEM images also clearly show the lattice fringes of all the Ni-based catalysts, with an interplanar spacing of 0.203 nm corresponding to the Ni (111) planes. Additionally, the EDS scanning spectra (Fig. S3) visually demonstrate the better dispersion of Ni elements on AlPO4. The quantity and strength of acid sites play crucial roles in the HDO process, and an abundance of acid sites facilitate the deoxygenation procedure of the intermediate products [34]. Therefore, NH3-TPD measurement was employed to explore the acid properties of the different catalysts. The NH3 desorption peaks can be categorized into weak acid sites (0-200 °C), medium acid sites (200-350 °C), and strong acid sites (350-550 °C) [35,36]. As illustrated in Fig. 4 and Table S2, Ni/AlPO4 catalyst exhibits three distinct desorption peaks at 119.2 °C, 255.5 °C, and 388.3 °C, with the total acid amount to 0.121 mmol/g. Conversely, the other two catalysts of Ni/CePO4 and Ni/LaPO4 display only a single peak at 218.6 °C and 266.2 °C respectively. The total acidity of all the catalysts ranks as the order of Ni/AlPO4 > Ni/LaPO4 > Ni/CePO4. A certain amount of strongly acidic sites contributes to the efficient deoxygenation process. [37] The NH3 molecules desorbed from Ni/AlPO4 are attributed to the terminal bridging OH groups on the phosphate carrier and the molecules associated with defect electron sites on metallic Al [38,39]. The hydrogen adsorption and desorption of the different catalysts were studied by utilizing H2-TPD measurement (Fig. 5 ). Different desorption peaks indicate the Ni-H bonds with different interaction strengths. In the H2-TPD curves, the desorption peaks in the mid-to-low temperature range (50-400 °C) are associated with large Ni particles, while the adsorption peaks in the high-temperature range (400-700 °C) are corresponding to small Ni particles [40]. As the desorption curves shown in Fig. 5, approximately 50 % of the peak area for the three catalysts is located in the low-temperature region, attributed to large Ni particles exposed on the phosphate support surface [41,42]. A quantitative measurement of the desorbed hydrogen amount was also conducted by integrating the peak areas, with the rank as Ni/AlPO4 > Ni/CePO4 > Ni/LaPO4. This indicates that Ni/AlPO4 possesses a strong hydrogen dissociation adsorption capacity, which corresponds to the small particle size distribution observed in TEM analysis. Ni/AlPO4 particles are the smallest in size and have the largest integral area for hydrogen adsorption. And small Ni particle size will facilitate the hydrogen dissociation and promote the hydrogen procedure. 3.2 HDO of lignin-derived phenolic compounds The catalytic activity of the different Ni-based catalysts in the HDO process of guaiacol was tested at the reaction temperature of 250 °C, and the results are shown in Table 2 . All the Ni-based phosphate catalysts achieve a complete conversion of guaiacol, which indicates that the introduction of phosphorus species improves the hydrogenation process of the reaction to a larger extent. As for the product selectivity, Ni/CePO4 and Ni/LaPO4 catalysts present a large proportion of alcohols, with 60.1 % and 53.7 % cyclohexanol, respectively. The weak acidity and the small specific surface area are probably the main reason for this poor deoxygenation performance. In the case of Ni/AlPO4 catalyst, the cyclohexane selectivity reaches 91.1 %, due to the abundant acid sites introduced by Al species. Thus, the cleavage of the CO bond is more easily to get under the catalysis of the acid site. On the other hand, Ni interacts more strongly with AlPO4 support, and the mutual electron transfer at the interface between Ni and AlPO4 provides advantage for the formation of Ni0 species and active hydrogen. The HDO products of all the Ni-based phosphate catalysts are mainly cyclohexane, cyclohexanol, methoxy cyclohexanol and o-toluene dimethyl ether. When the HDO reaction was conducted using pure supports, there was little substrate conversion. When using AlPO4 support as catalyst, the conversion of guaiacol is only 22.5 %, and the products were mainly 1,3-Dimethoxy benzene. This phenomenon is due to the limited hydrogenation of guaiacol in the absence of Ni metal sites, which is catalyzed by a Friedel-Crafts-type reaction with carbonyl ions (CH3 +) as intermediates in the presence of the acidic supports [43,44]. When using the conventional Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, the cyclohexane yield is only 6.3 %, with a high percentage of cyclohexanols among the product distribution. The comparison between Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/AlPO4 demonstrates that the introduction of phosphorus species substantially increases the cyclohexane yield. In order to obtain more insightful information about catalyst activity and reaction pathway, the effects of reaction temperature and hydrogen pressure on the conversion of guaiacol over Ni/AlPO4 catalysts were investigated. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the conversion of guaiacol remains 99.9 % in the 220-260 °C range. The conversion of guaiacol to phenyl cyclohexanol and methoxy cyclohexanol is observed at low temperature. During the HDO process, the hydrogenation of the benzene ring to produce cyclohexanol and methoxy cyclohexanol is dominated at low temperature. With the increase of temperature, the deoxygenation effect is enhanced, and the cyclohexane yield over Ni/AlPO4 catalyst enables to reach 91.1 % at the temperature of 250 °C. Based on the reaction results and the previous studies [45,46], it can be concluded that guaiacol is firstly converted through hydrogenation pathway, followed by the CO bond cleavage. The bond energy of C(Ar)-OH (456 KJ/mol) is about 70 KJ/mol higher than that of C(Ar)-CH3 (375 KJ/mol) based on the bond energy kinetics calculation in the previous study [47,48], so the content of methoxy cyclohexanol decreases more rapidly than that of cyclohexanol when the temperature is increased. Interestingly, the content of cyclohexanol also increases when the temperature increases from 220 to 250 °C, which is due to the cleavage of the CO bond in methoxy cyclohexanol. And the intermediate product cyclohexanol is completely converted to cyclohexane (99.9 %) at 260 °C. The results of Ni/AlPO4 catalysts at different reaction times were investigated to clarify their reaction pathways. As shown in Fig. 6b, the yield of cyclohexane increased sharply from 16.6 % to 91.1 % as the time was increased from 1 h to 4 h, while the percentage of alcohol products decreased gradually with the reaction time, and the yield of cyclohexane remained unchanged when the reaction time was longer than 4 h. Meanwhile, the yield of cyclopentanol in the side reaction also increased with the increase of reaction time. The formation of cyclopentanol is mainly due to the Favorskii rearrangement reaction of guaiacol in the presence of base site [49,50]. And the presence of Al atoms in this work also can provide some base site (OH−). Other reaction conditions such as hydrogen pressure were also investigated to obtain the optimum reaction parameters. As shown in Fig. S4, the initial hydrogen pressure had a significant effect on guaiacol conversion and alkane selectivity than the reaction temperature. Similar to the increase in alkane yield with the increase in reaction temperature, the deoxygenation process was carried out thoroughly with the increase in hydrogen pressure from 0.6 MPa to 1.0 MPa. The product distribution did not change much when the hydrogen pressure was increased to 1.2 MPa, which indicated that the optimum hydrogen pressure was 1 MPa. The same catalyst dosage was also optimized and the results are shown in Fig. S4b, where the optimum dosage was determined by a series of feeding experiments to be 0.05 g. Interestingly, when the catalyst dosage was 0.06 g, no cyclopentanol was detected in the product, but only cyclohexane. This suggests that cyclopentanol only appeared as an intermediate product, possibly due to the small amount of product present because of insufficient catalyst dosage. The effect of solvents on the HDO performance over Ni/AlPO4 catalyst was also investigated by comparing the alkane solvents and ethanol solvent (Table S3). The results show that the guaiacol conversion and the cyclohexane selectivity are both more than 90 % when the HDO reaction is carried out in alkane solvents, including n-hexane, n-octane and dodecane. While, when the solvent is replaced by ethanol, the conversion becomes to almost zero. Based on previous studies [51,52], when ethanol is used in the reaction system, they will be extensively absorbed at the surface Ni active center. And this uptake makes the substrate adsorption hindered, thus lowering down the guaiacol conversion. The recycle performance of the catalysts is a key factor to evaluate the commercial applications. In this study, recycle HDO reaction was performed using Ni/AlPO4 catalysts. As shown in Table S4, the guaiacol conversion to cyclohexane presents no decrease in each recycle compared to the fresh catalyst in the first three runs. With the recycle test going on, the cyclohexane selectivity gradually decreases. This decrease of cyclohexane selectivity is probably due to the carbon deposition covering the active catalysis site. According to the XRD pattern of the fresh and spent Ni/AlPO4 catalysts in Fig. S5, the peak of Ni metal phase in the spent catalyst becomes larger and more pronounced, as a result of the increase of the metal particle size. The catalytic activity is strongly related to the Ni metal dispersion and Ni metal particle size significantly [53]. According to previous studies [54–56], more acidic catalysts have a greater likelihood of adsorption while the acidic sites of the catalyst are covered with carbon deposits leading to a decrease in acidity. In addition, the peaks suspected to be carbon deposition are also found in the XRD plot of the spent catalyst with strong peak intensity [57,58]. In order to investigate the states of Ni metal before and after reaction, we performed XPS tests of Ni to analyze the changes of Ni valence state (Fig. S6). After the stability test, there was a decrease in the Ni0 valence state of the catalyst, which was due to oxidation. Overall, the catalyst still maintains its metallic properties mostly after the catalytic reaction. Characterization of the catalysts through TGA (Thermogravimetric Analysis) was performed after the reaction to verify the existence of carbon deposition (Fig. S7). The carbon species present in all catalysts can be broadly categorized into three groups based on their decomposition temperatures. The weight loss observed below 200 °C is attributed to the evaporation of water adsorbed on the catalyst. The weight loss between 200 °C and 400 °C primarily corresponds to amorphous carbon, while weight loss above 400 °C is due to the formation of CO or CO2 from crystalline carbon [59]. For the fresh catalyst, the weight loss at 200 °C is primarily due to the evaporation of water molecules. The increased weight loss observed at 400–550 °C in the catalyst after 5 cycles indicates the presence of carbon deposition. This carbon deposition is identified as the main factor hindering the catalyst's activity. The transformation pathway of guaiacol is inferred from the above characterization and experimental results as shown in Fig. 7 . Guaiacol is first directly hydrogenated at low temperature by active hydrogen to form the intermediate of methoxy cyclohexanol. Methoxy cyclohexanol continues to be demethoxylated and subsequently forms the cyclohexanol. The abundance of active hydrogen plays a pivotal role in removing methoxy groups under the catalysis of Ni0 active sites. Cyclohexanol is then converted to cyclohexene with the assisted dehydration over the acid site. In this case, the acidic site consists of an electron-deficient aluminum atom and a P-OH on a phosphohydroxyl group [60,61]. Cyclohexene is not detected in the products throughout HDO reaction, which is contributed to the good hydrogen dissociation ability of Ni/AlPO4. The final product cyclohexane is generated by rapid hydrogenation as soon as cyclohexene is formed. Another pathway for the intermediate cyclohexanol is to form cyclohexane by breaking the C(ar)-OH bond in the presence of active hydrogen. Other typical lignin-derived phenolic compounds with different structures and functional groups, including phenol, p-cresol, 4-propyl guaiacol, anisole, and diphenyl ether were also tested to investigate the HDO properties of Ni/AlPO4 catalyst. As results shown in Table 3 , the conversion of p-cresol is 99.9 %, and the products consist of 40.6 % p-methyl cyclohexane, 57.3 % methyl cyclohexane and 2.1 % 4-methyl cyclohexanol. The methylation during the HDO process is caused by the para-position methyl group of p-cresol, which leads to the instability of the structure [62]. When phenol and 4-propyl guaiacol are used as substrates, the conversions are both 99.9 %, and the cycloalkane selectivities both exceed 90 %. In addition, the ether substrates show commendable HDO performance over Ni/AlPO4 catalyst. For example, the conversion of anisole is 99.9 % and the cyclohexane selectivity is 66.2 %. The diphenyl ether also exhibits similar results, with the dominated cycloalkane products (cyclohexane selectivity of 55.2 % and methylcyclohexane yield of 44.8 %). This study reveals that Ni/AlPO4 is an effective catalyst for the HDO process of various lignin-derived compounds, which is due to the abundant acid sites, large surface area, and small Ni metal particle size of the catalyst. The HDO properties of lignin-oil containing various phenolic compounds were also tested by using Ni/AlPO4 catalyst. The detailed composition of the raw and upgraded lignin-oil is shown in Table 4 . The main components of lignin-oil are 16.0 % hydrocarbons, 9.9 % alkylphenols, 68.9 % guaiacols and syringols, and 5.2 % other oxygenated compounds. The raw lignin-oil contains a high proportion of unsaturated alkanes and oxygenated compounds, making it unsuitable for direct usage as fuels. Therefore, it is necessary to undergo upgrading. After the catalytic HDO of lignin-oil with Ni/AlPO4 catalyst at 250 °C, the hydrocarbon content increases from 16.0 % to 88.6 %, and most of hydrocarbons are cycloalkane compounds. The alkylphenol and guaiacol components are reduced from 68.9 % to 11.4 %. The HDO process over Ni/AlPO4 catalyst involves the collaboration of metal site and acid site to transform phenolic compounds into cycloalkane products. 4 Conclusions This study proposed a dual metal-acid strategy by synthesizing various Ni-based phosphate catalysts and explored their HDO performance of lignin-derived phenolic compounds. Ni/AlPO4 catalyst demonstrates the highest catalytic activity and the highest selectivity towards cycloalkanes. Under reaction conditions of 250 °C and 1 MPa H2, the guaiacol conversion reaches 99 %, with cyclohexane selectivity exceeding 90 %. Characterization results reveal that Ni/AlPO4 catalyst possesses strong acidity, large specific surface area, and enhanced hydrogen dissociation capabilities derived from the small Ni metal particle size. Moreover, most phenolic compounds derived from lignin and raw lignin-oil also exhibit excellent HDO performance over Ni/AlPO4, leading to a significant improvement in hydrocarbon content. The recycle of the catalyst is able to maintain high alkane selectivity in three run, after which the product selectivity decreases due to the carbon buildup and metal flaking. Based on the experimental data and characterization results, the Ni/AlPO4 catalytic reaction pathway mechanism is proposed to elucidate the variances in structure and performance among different Ni-based phosphate catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Lignin-derived products possess high carbon content and offer significant potential to be used as liquid fuels. However, they also contain high oxygen element and unstable functional groups. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is an effective method for upgrading lignin-derived phenolic compounds to produce high-quality liquid biofuels. In this study, a series of Ni-based phosphate catalysts incorporating various metals (Al, Ce, La) were prepared and employed for the HDO of lignin-derived phenolic compounds. The results showed that Ni/AlPO4 had the most efficient HDO performance, with guaiacol conversion of 99.9 % and cyclohexane selectivity of 91.1 % at the reaction temperature of 250 °C. Various catalyst characterization measurements were conducted to assess the impact of metal phosphate species on the crystallography, morphology, physicochemical characteristics and surface properties. Results indicated that Ni/AlPO4 catalyst exhibited stronger acidity, smaller Ni particle sizes and larger specific surface area than other Ni-based phosphate catalysts. Based on the characterization results and experimental data, the corresponding HDO reaction pathways and mechanisms were also proposed. Ni/AlPO4 catalyst was also applied to the HDO of various lignin-derived phenol compounds and achieved a good HDO effect. Moreover, the catalytic upgrading of lignin-oil was also carried out, and a high proportion of hydrocarbon products that increased from 16.0 % to 88.6 % was obtained. This Ni/AlPO4 catalyst provides potential reference for the HDO application of lignin-derived phenolic compounds for the production of hydrocarbon liquid fuels.
